case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 234 of 1964 filed by the State of Maharashtra

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 234 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated November 8, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 1135 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 8, 1963 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1135 of 1962. R. Prem, S. P. Nayyar for R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: Bombay High Court set aside conviction of Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas under s.92 Factories Act read with r.3-A Bombay Factories Rules, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The State of Maharashtra appeals against the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay dated November 8, 1963 by which the High Court set aside, the companyviction of one Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas  since deceased and represented by his widow  and the fine imposed on him, under s. 92 of the Factories Act, 1948 read with r. 3-A of the Bombay Factories Rules, 1950.

facts.text: Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas was a lessee from Port Trust Bombay of an open plot of land

anchor.surface_text: Purshottamdas Ranchboddas was a lessee from the Port Trust Bombay of an open plot of land. He established a factory called the Sunderdas Saw Mills.

facts.text: Purshottamdas established a factory called Sunderdas Saw Mills

anchor.surface_text: He established a factory called the Sunderdas Saw Mills. He closed down the factory on April 1, 1957. In July 1957, the ex-workers of the factory companybined to-ether to form five partnerships

facts.text: Factory closed down on April 1, 1957

anchor.surface_text: He closed down the factory on April 1, 1957. In July 1957, the ex-workers of the factory companybined to-ether to form five partnerships and by agreements of leave and licence,

facts.text: In July 1957 ex-workers formed five partnerships

anchor.surface_text: In July 1957, the ex-workers of the factory companybined to-ether to form five partnerships and by agreements of leave and licence, Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas gave in their use, the premises of the factory and the machinery installed there.

facts.text: Purshottamdas gave premises and machinery to partnerships by leave and licence agreements

anchor.surface_text: and by agreements of leave and licence, Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas gave in their use, the premises of the factory and the machinery installed there. He himself did number join any of the five partnerships.

facts.text: Purshottamdas did not join any of the five partnerships

anchor.surface_text: He himself did number join any of the five partnerships. The licensees were to pay a fixed sum for the use of the premises and the machines.

facts.text: Licensees to pay fixed sum for use of premises and machines

anchor.surface_text: The licensees were to pay a fixed sum for the use of the premises and the machines. It appears that some of the workers who were number taken in as partners companyplained that the closure of the factory was a sham.

facts.text: Some workers complained that closure was sham, no action taken, no finding that closure unreal

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some of the workers who were number taken in as partners companyplained that the closure of the factory was a sham. No action was taken on this companyplaint and -there is numberfinding in this case that the closure of the factory was unreal.

facts.text: In 1959 prosecution under s.92 for no notice under s.71 and no licence renewal under r.4, ended in acquittal

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1959, a prosecution was started under S. 92 of the Factories Act on the charge that the original licensee of the factory had number given numberice under s. 7 1  of the start of the factory and had number renewed the licence under r. 4 of the Bombay Factories Rules, 1950. This ended in an acquittal

facts.text: Acquittal because no declaration under s.85

anchor.surface_text: This ended in an acquittal since Government had number declared these premises as a factory under s. 85 of the Act, as it companyld, if the workers  although number employed by the owner were working with the permission of or under an agreement with the owner.

facts.text: Notification issued under s.85 on September 29, 1960 specifying places of five partnerships as factory

anchor.surface_text: On September 29, 1960, a numberification was issued under s. That numberification specified the places where the five partnerships were working as factory.

facts.text: On November 10, 1959 five separate complaints filed for failure to take out five licences

anchor.surface_text: On November 10, 1959, five separate companyplaints were filed for failure to take out five licences. The charge was that Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas was the owner of the factory and hence an occupier

facts.text: Charge: Purshottamdas owner of factory and occupier, workmen working under agreement with him

anchor.surface_text: The charge was that Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas was the owner of the factory and hence an occupier and the workmen were working under an agreement with him.

facts.text: Purshottamdas defended that he had no control over the five firms

anchor.surface_text: The owner defended himself by stating that he had numbercontrol over the five firms and he companyld number enforce the provisions of the Factories Act. This defence was number accepted.

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate convicted Purshottamdas, fined Rs. 201 for first offence and Rs. 25 for subsequent

anchor.surface_text: Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas was held to have become an occupier by reason of the numberification and, therefore, to, be companypelled to take out a licence under r. 3-A of the Bombay Factories Rules. He was fined Rs. 201/- for the first offence and Rs. 25/- for the subsequent offences.

facts.text: Purshottamdas appealed, died during pendency, appeal continued by legal representative under s.431 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Purushottamdas Ranchhoddas appealed but died during the pendency of the appeal. As the sentence was one of fine the appeal was companytinued by his legal representative under s. 431 of the Coda of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Bombay High Court set aside conviction and fine

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court set aside the companyviction and fine and number the present appeal has been filed by the State of Maharashtra on special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal filed by State on special leave

anchor.surface_text: and number the present appeal has been filed by the State of Maharashtra on special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Court found Purshottamdas had no ultimate control over affairs of five partnership firms

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 2 n  of the Act an occupier of a factory means the person who has the ultimate companytrol over the affairs of the factory. If one goes by this definition, Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas was number an occupier if he had number the ultimate companytrol

facts.text: Agreements showed premises given to partnership firms for periodic payment, no control by Purshottamdas

anchor.surface_text: In the, present case the agreements show that the, premises were given over to partnership firms in return for a periodic payment. The agreements show that the licensees of the premises bound themselves to carry on the manufacturing process on their own and Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas had numbercontrol over them.

facts.text: High Court considered clauses and concluded partnerships independent of control of owner

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has companysidered the clauses and companye to the companyclusion that the partnerships were independent of the companytrol of the owner and the workers cannot be said to be working with his permission or under agreement with him.

facts.text: Conditions for notification under s.85(1)(ii) did not exist

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the companyditions for the numberification hardly existed.

issues.text: the true construction of S. 85 of the Factories Act on which different views have been expressed by the High Court and the Court below

anchor.surface_text: Only one question arises in this appeal and it is the true construction of S. 85 of the Factories Act on which different views have been expressed by the High Court and the Court below.

issues.text: whether s. 85(1)(ii) covers the present case

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, differing from the Presidency Magistrate, Mazgaon, held that s. 85 1 ii did number cover the present case. We think the High Court was right.

issues.text: whether Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas was an occupier having the ultimate control over the affairs of the factory under s. 2(n)

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 2 n of the Act an occupier of a factory means the person who has the ultimate companytrol over the affairs of the factory. If one goes by this definition, Purshottamdas Ranchhoddas was number an occupier
